Biography News Budget – FY26 District Office 573 East Fordham Road (Entrance on Hoffman Street) Bronx, NY 10458 718-842-8100 phone 347-597-8570 fax Legislative Office 250 Broadway, Suite 1759 New York, NY 10007 212-788-6966 phone 212-788-8977 fax Search for: Visit the Council We're located at New York City Hall. Council Members each have an office at 250 Broadway , as well as offices in each of their districts. We want to hear from you You can reach us via social media, email, paper mail, or at your district office. For issues specific to a neighborhood, it's best to contact the Council Member representing that community. Have questions, comments or feedback? Email us here. New York City Council Search for: Find My District Budget Committees Land Use Legislation Press Releases Translate this page Google Translate District 15 Oswald Feliz Morrisania, Claremont Village-Claremont (East), Crotona Park East, Crotona Park, Mount Eden-Claremont (West), Claremont Park, Mount Hope, Fordham Heights, West Farms, Tremont, Belmont, University Heights (North)-Fordham, Bedford Park, Soundview-Bruckner-Bronx River, Pelham Parkway-Van Nest, Allerton, Bronx Park Budget – FY26 All organizations requesting FY 26 discretionary expense funding from Council Member Feliz should complete the supplemental application at their earliest convenience . In order to be eligible for funds from our office, organizations must complete two applications: FY26 Expense Application (City-wide) Deadline: February 19 th , 2025 For any issues or questions regarding the FY 2025 application, please contact discretionary@council.nyc.gov FY26 Supplementary Application (Member-specific) Deadline: February 27 th , 2025 Organizations interested in receiving funds from the Black, Latino, and Asian Caucus (BLAC) must complete the following application: FY26 Discretionary Funding Supplemental Form Deadline: February 19th Any questions regarding this application must be referred to BLAcaucus@council.nyc.gov Non-city entities requesting FY 26 Discretionary Capital Funding from Council Member Feliz must submit the supplemental application at their earliest convenience Much like discretionary funds, in order for proposals to be considered two applications must be submitted: CapGrants Application There are two deadlines for this application February 20 th : applies if your project requests any funding from Borough Presidents (including those groups that are also requesting funding from the Council or Department of Cultural Affairs) March 20 th : applies if your project is only requesting funding from the Council and/or the Department of Cultural Affairs Supplementary Applications (Member-specific); Non-city/Not-for-profit Entities Rolling Deadline: February 27 th Schools Deadline: March 20 th If you are seeking information on an existing allocation or contract from FY22 , FY23 , or FY24 , please refer to the Mayor’s Office of Contract Services (MOCS) Discretionary Award Tracker . Any questions or concerns regarding the member-specific supplemental applications or past designations can be referred to the Budget Director, Santiago Baena, at sbaena@council.nyc.gov . New York City Council Search for: Find My District Budget Committees Land Use Legislation Press Releases Translate this page Google Translate District 15 Oswald Feliz Morrisania, Claremont Village-Claremont (East), Crotona Park East, Crotona Park, Mount Eden-Claremont (West), Claremont Park, Mount Hope, Fordham Heights, West Farms, Tremont, Belmont, University Heights (North)-Fordham, Bedford Park, Soundview-Bruckner-Bronx River, Pelham Parkway-Van Nest, Allerton, Bronx Park Biography Councilmember Oswald Feliz is a lifelong resident of the Bronx, who proudly represents the 15th Council District – which includes the neighborhoods of Fordham, Belmont, East Tremont, West Farms, Van Nest, and Allerton. Oswald is a proud graduate of public schools in the Bronx, including P.S.46, M.S.45, Walton High School, Bronx Community College, and Lehman College. Eventually, he attended law school and obtained a law degree from CUNY School of Law. Prior to becoming a City Councilmember, Oswald worked as a tenant lawyer, and successfully defended Bronx residents in eviction and landlord harassment cases. Oswald represented a tenant association in a building-wide case against a landlord who failed to keep their building in good condition, and negotiated a settlement wherein tenants received approximately $100,000 from their landlord. In addition to working as a lawyer, Oswald served as an adjunct professor at Hostos Community College, where he had the privilege of teaching reading and writing to disadvantaged students in the Bronx. As a Councilmember, Oswald is dedicated to improving his home of the Bronx. He is committed to ensuring that access to good schools, safe streets, and opportunities for growth not be determined based on the neighborhood that one resides in. In addition to working as a lawyer, Oswald served as an adjunct professor at Hostos Community College, where he had the privilege of teaching reading and writing to disadvantaged students in the Bronx. As a Councilmember, Oswald is dedicated to improving his home of the Bronx. He is committed to ensuring that access to good schools, safe streets, and opportunities for growth not be determined based on the neighborhood that one resides in.
